comment._content: Why did the Great Eastern have/need canons?

comment.author: 7194982@N07
comment._content: I'd like to second Stillbase's question as to why the Great Eastern had canons, as a civilian ship - is this definitely the Great Eastern?

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/roblangham] 

Hi Rob,

I've talked to the Curator of Historic Photographs here about this question and we seem to be more questions then answers.

We cannot locate anything that mentions her having these canons and if you look at the image, the carriages are not chocked so they would move about when the ship rolled.  Also, the breach lines are a single rope spliced at each end onto an eye, therefore, these guns could not be run out easily.  The gun ports are also not proper ones – they have no lids to keep the water out.

The guns are larger than would be expected for signal guns (usually 3 pounders).

However, we are fairly certain that it is Great Eastern, as it does show the cable laying equipment.

We would love to hear your thoughts.

Thanks

Lucinda
